A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$.
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A monoid homomorphism is a map between two monoids, and a monoid is defined as a set equipped with an associative binary operation and an identity element. Therefore, the concept of a monoid homomorphism depends on the associative law.

A ring isomorphism is a special type of ring homomorphism, and a ring homomorphism is defined between two rings. A ring itself is defined as a set equipped with two binary operations (addition and multiplication) that satisfy certain properties, including associativity. Therefore, the concept of a ring isomorphism depends on the associative law.

A Euclidean function is defined in the context of a Euclidean domain, which is a type of integral domain. An integral domain is a commutative ring with no zero divisors, and a ring is defined with associative operations. Therefore, the concept of a Euclidean function depends on the associative law.

A free system of generators (basis) is defined in the context of modules, which are generalizations of vector spaces. Modules are defined over rings, and rings have associative operations. Therefore, the concept of a free system of generators depends on the associative law.

The Galois group of a polynomial splitting field is a group of automorphisms, and automorphisms are isomorphisms from a mathematical structure to itself. The concept of isomorphisms in algebraic structures like fields and rings depends on associative operations. Therefore, the concept of a Galois group depends on the associative law.

An integral ring homomorphism is a type of ring homomorphism, and a ring homomorphism is defined between two rings. Rings have associative operations. Therefore, the concept of an integral ring homomorphism depends on the associative law.

A finite field is a field with a finite number of elements. Fields are algebraic structures with two operations (addition and multiplication) that are associative. Therefore, the concept of a finite field depends on the associative law.

The orbit of a point under a group action is defined in the context of group theory. Groups are algebraic structures with an associative binary operation. Therefore, the concept of an orbit depends on the associative law.

A transposition is a specific type of permutation, and permutations are elements of a symmetric group. Groups are defined with an associative binary operation. Therefore, the concept of a transposition depends on the associative law.

A ring isomorphism is a special type of ring homomorphism, and a ring homomorphism is defined between two rings. Therefore, the concept of a ring isomorphism depends on the concept of a ring homomorphism.
